source.title: Determining molar concentration of 1X Cy Dye via NanoDrop 2000c

source.body:
Note: In case if your institution does not have NanoDrop, please use a UV spectrophotometer of your choice.
For Cy2 - measure absorption at 489 nm. The Cy2 extinction coefficient is 150,000. Divide absorption at 550 nm by 0.15 to get concentration in μM.
Molar Concentration (mM) = (Average μM concentration X 250 dilution factor)/1000.
For Cy3 - measure absorption at 550 nm. The Cy3 extinction coefficient is 150,000. Divide absorption at 550nm by 0.15 to get concentration in μM.
Molar Concentration (mM) = (Average μM concentration X 250 dilution factor)/1000.
For Cy5 - measure absorption at 650 nm. The Cy5 extinction coefficient is 250,000. Divide absorption at 650 nm by 0.25 to get concentration in μM.
Molar Concentration (mM) = (Average μM concentration X 250 dilution factor)/1000.
For Cy7 - measure absorption at 750 nm. The Cy7 extinction coefficient is 200,000. Divide absorption at 650 nm by 0.2 to get concentration in μM.
Molar Concentration (mM) = (Average μM concentration X 250 dilution factor)/1000.

source.description: The pilot conjugations will be used to determine the optimal D/P for the specific antibody tested. Every antibody will have an optimal D/P.

source.title: unconjugated primary antibody
Preparing calculations for pilot conjugations

source.description:
Use Form-7 to calculate the volume of antibody, 20X borate, 1X PBS and dye needed for the pilot reaction
  • Input any cell that is colored blue
  • “Dye purity” is the percent (%) reactive dye information that will be on the Certificate of Analysis and is lot dependent. Enter the information on Form 7 in decimal form (i.e. 90.2% = 0.902). If the information is not available, use the following website to look up the CoA using the lot#:
  • https://www.cytivalifesciences.com/en/us/support/quality/certificates
  • “Loading” is the initial ratio of dye to antibody that is used in the conjugation. The loading is calculated as: Initial D/P divided by expected efficiency (expressed as a decimal). Refer to Table 2.1 for the appropriate values. For example, if targeting a Cy3 labeling at a D/P of 3.5, the “Loading” would be 4.67 (3.5/0.75).
  • Choose a dye dilution that will allow you to add a minimum of 2 μL of solution while not overly diluting the entire sample. As you adjust the “dye dilution” cell on Form-7, the “μL dye” will change accordingly. This volume is the amount of the diluted dye that you need to add. See Section
  • 'Materials'
  • for the preparation of the working dye solutions. If the dilution needed is not described in Section 'Materials', adjust the calculations accordingly. You should prepare at least twice the volume of working solution that will need to be added to the conjugation.
  • If there is enough antibody, repeat the calculations for the second D/P target.
  • Refer to Figure 2.1, for an example of calculating these values.
  • On Form-7, there are two choices of calculations depending on your starting antibody concentration.
“Dye purity” is the percent (%) reactive dye information that will be on the Certificate of Analysis and is lot dependent. Enter the information on Form 7 in decimal form (i.e. 90.2% = 0.902). If the information is not available, use the following website to look up the CoA using the lot#:
https://www.cytivalifesciences.com/en/us/support/quality/certificates
  • “Loading” is the initial ratio of dye to antibody that is used in the conjugation. The loading is calculated as: Initial D/P divided by expected efficiency (expressed as a decimal). Refer to Table 2.1 for the appropriate values. For example, if targeting a Cy3 labeling at a D/P of 3.5, the “Loading” would be 4.67 (3.5/0.75).
  • Choose a dye dilution that will allow you to add a minimum of 2 μL of solution while not overly diluting the entire sample. As you adjust the “dye dilution” cell on Form-7, the “μL dye” will change accordingly. This volume is the amount of the diluted dye that you need to add. See Section
  • 'Materials'
  • for the preparation of the working dye solutions. If the dilution needed is not described in Section 'Materials', adjust the calculations accordingly. You should prepare at least twice the volume of working solution that will need to be added to the conjugation.
  • If there is enough antibody, repeat the calculations for the second D/P target.
  • Refer to Figure 2.1, for an example of calculating these values.
  • On Form-7, there are two choices of calculations depending on your starting antibody concentration.
Choose a dye dilution that will allow you to add a minimum of 2 μL of solution while not overly diluting the entire sample. As you adjust the “dye dilution” cell on Form-7, the “μL dye” will change accordingly. This volume is the amount of the diluted dye that you need to add. See Section
'Materials'
for the preparation of the working dye solutions. If the dilution needed is not described in Section 'Materials', adjust the calculations accordingly. You should prepare at least twice the volume of working solution that will need to be added to the conjugation.
  • If there is enough antibody, repeat the calculations for the second D/P target.
  • Refer to Figure 2.1, for an example of calculating these values.
  • On Form-7, there are two choices of calculations depending on your starting antibody concentration.

source.title: Determining molar concentration of 1X Cy Dye via NanoDrop 2000c

source.description: Open the NanoDrop 2000c software version 7.2.1.1 program located on the desktop of the NanonDrop computer.

source.title: Overview

source.description:
Initially perform a pilot conjugation (~
-
) to determine the optimal D/P of the antibody. Then assume a 100% efficiency for the scale up conjugation, targeting the optimal D/P selected after the initial conjugation. This will avoid the possibility of over labeling the antibody. Please save
for any trouble shooting.

source.title: purified Ab
Pre-Experiment Check

source.description: Antibody should be purified and in 1X PBS (w/azide).

source.title: Pre-Experiment Check

source.description: If the antibody was ordered as purified, confirm there aren't any incompatible additives by checking the data sheet and the Purification Guide section of the Chemistry SOP.

source.title: Pre-Experiment Check

source.description: Take a reading of the antibody using the NanoDrop (refer to section 'Quantitative Assessment of Pilot Direct Conjugate via NanoDrop2000c' of Pilot Conjugation) to check the concentration and ensure it is pure.

source.body:
• If the concentration is much higher than what the vial says, then this indicates the presence of BSA, which will interfere with the conjugation. The antibody will need to be purified if this is the case.
  • If antibody concentration is below , concentrate to using Amicon filters. Refer to Section 7.1 ('Evaluate Need for Purification as per Formulation') of the Cell DIVE Antibody Purification manual.

source.title: Pre-Experiment Check

source.description:
Use purified antibody (35 μg minimum) at a concentration of ≤
.

source.title: Pre-Experiment Check

source.description:
Be sure to save at least
to be validated alongside the direct conjugate.

source.title: unconjugated primary antibody
Scale-Up Conjugation Procedure

source.description: Prepare the 1X dye solution and measure the concentration as described previously (Section 'Determining molar concentration of 1X Cy Dye via NanoDrop 2000c' of Pilot Conjugation).

source.title: Scale-Up Conjugation Procedure

source.description: Use the optimal D/P obtained after the pilot conjugation as a target. Assume a 100% efficiency upon scaleup. The “Loading” value used in Form-7 will be the optimal D/P. For example, if you determined the optimal D/P was 4.0, than the “Loading” parameter in Form-7 will be 4.0. This will prevent the possibility of overlabeling the antibody.

source.title: Scale-Up Conjugation Procedure

source.description: Measure the concentration of the antibody as described in Section 7.8 ('Confirming the complete removal of purified antibody via NanoDrop') in the Purification Manual.

source.title: Scale-Up Conjugation Procedure

source.description: Prepare the antibody conjugation solution as described previously (Section 'Preparing calculations for pilot conjugations' of Pilot Conjugation). Use Form-7 to determine the appropriate amounts of all the reagents.

source.title: Scale-Up Conjugation Procedure

source.description: Add the appropriate amount of dye while vortexing at low speed.

source.title: Scale-Up Conjugation Procedure

source.description:
Leave the mixture in complete darkness at
for
.

source.title: Scale-Up Conjugation Procedure

source.description: Prepare Zeba desalting columns (0.5 mL) immediately following the start of incubation. If you are conjugating more than 70 μg of antibody, then one Zeba column will not be enough. You can split the conjugation between two columns (4 columns total per conjugation). If you are conjugating more than 150 μg of antibody, switch to PD-10 columns.

source.title: Purification using PD-10 columns

source.body: PD-10 columns are gravity fed and will need a longer preparation time. The standard sample size is - . If a lower volume is used, the conjugate will be further diluted.

source.title: Purification using PD-10 columns

source.description: Remove the top cap and discard the column storage solution.

source.title: Purification using PD-10 columns

source.description: Cut the sealed end of the column at the notch.

source.title: Purification using PD-10 columns

source.description: Fill the column with 1X PBS and let the buffer enter the packed resin.

source.title: Purification using PD-10 columns

source.description: Repeat this filling and elution 4 times, then discard the flow-through.

source.title: Purification using PD-10 columns

source.description:
Add
-
to the top of the column. Dilute your conjugate with 1X PBS if volume is less than
.

source.title: conjugation solution
Purification using PD-10 columns

source.description: Once the conjugate solution has completely entered the column, elute with 1X PBS until the colored conjugate has completely eluted.

source.body: NOTE: If the color is hard to see, the eluent fractions can be measured with the NanoDrop to determine if all the conjugate has been eluted.

source.title: Scale-up Conjugate Evaluation

source.description: Measure D/P and determine yield and efficiency using procedure described earlier.

source.title: Scale-up Conjugate Evaluation

source.description: If the D/P calculated is too low, more dye can be conjugated using the established procedure.

source.title: Scale-up Conjugate Evaluation

source.description: Once an acceptable D/P ratio has been achieved, add stabilizing solution, 1X PBS and determine final conjugate antibody concentration.

source.title: Antibody Pilot Conjugation

source.description:
Remove the antibody from it's storage location and allow it to equilibrate to
for

description:
Scope
The purpose of this protocol is to conjugate purified antibodies to Cy dyes. Antibody conjugation involves combining dyes with antibodies to achieve a fluorescently labeled antibody. Each antibody will be labeled with a molar equivalent of dye; the quantitative output of this is deemed D/P. In the initial conjugation step, each antibody will be labeled with differing D/P levels and validated to determine which level is optimal.
